newsitem.title: CANADA: BASEBALL-ORIOLES, RANGERS MOVE CLOSER TO POST-SEASON SPOTS.
newsitem.headline: BASEBALL-ORIOLES, RANGERS MOVE CLOSER TO POST-SEASON SPOTS.

text.p: The Orioles and Rangers moved closer to securing post-season spots on Thursday as the Red Sox were eliminated and the Mariners were hanging by a thread heading into the final weekend of the season.

In Toronto, rookie Rocky Coppinger came within two outs of his first shutout and Brady Anderson and Cal Ripken homered as the Orioles widened their lead in the American League wild-card race by defeating the Blue Jays 4-1.
The win moved Baltimore 2 1/2 games ahead of Seattle and eliminated Boston from the wild-card chase.
Coppinger (10-6) allowed one run and five hits over 8 1/3 innings with no walks and seven strikeouts.

"Going to bed last night I knew it was important. This is the biggest series of the year for us," Coppinger said. "I was nervous going out at the beginning and then Cal's three-run homer really made me relax. In your first season in the big leagues, to get a win like this is big."

Anderson tied Bobby Bonds' major-league record by leading off a game with a homer for the 11th time this season. It was the 48th homer of the year for Anderson, who had three hits to break out of a 3-for-21 slump.
Ripken became the fourth Oriole this season to collect at least 100 RBI, breaking the team record. Ripken has 12 RBI in his last five games.
"A lot of things happened so fast, we won the World Series in my second year and I think I took it for granted," said Ripken. "I've been through rebuilding and now I can see the World Series."
In Boston, Rudy Pemberton's two-run single capped a four-run first inning and three relievers as the Red Sox scored a 5-3 victory over the New York Yankees.
The Yankees had clinched the American League East title on Wednesday.

In Texas, Will Clark capped a four-run third inning with a go-ahead sacrifice fly and the Rangers took advantage of some shoddy defence to stand on the verge of the A.L. West title with a 6-5 victory over the California Angels.

The Rangers, who began as the Washington Senators in 1961 and moved to Texas for the 1972 season, are still looking for their first post-season berth. The next Rangers win or Seattle loss gives Texas the Western Division title.
If the Rangers, 3 1/2 games up on Seattle, lose their last three games and the Mariners win their last four, a one-game playoff will be held at Seattle on Tuesday.
The Rangers benefited from two key California errors to overcome a 3-0 deficit in the bottom of the third.

Mark McLemore led off with a walk off Angels starter Jim Abbott (2-18). One out later, Darryl Hamilton singled before Ivan Rodriguez delivered an RBI double. Rusty Greer hit a flyball to centre field that Darin Erstad dropped, scoring Hamilton to pull Texas within 3-2.
Juan Gonzalez hit a smash to third baseman Randy Velarde, who let the ball skip through his legs, tying the game and sending Greer to third. Clark followed with a sacrifice fly.

In Oakland, Tony Batista delivered a two-run single and Mike Bordick drew a bases-loaded walk and scored on a wild pitch in a four-run eighth inning as the Athletics rallied for a 7-5 win over the Mariners, damaging Seattle's playoff hopes.
The A's took their first lead in the sixth on an inside-the-park home run by catcher Terry Steinbach.
Steinbach's long fly to right eluded Jay Buhner and caromed back to the infield. The slow-footed Steinbach was able to race around the bases before second baseman Joey Cora could retrieve the ball.
It was the first inside-the-park homer for the A's since Felix Jose's in 1990 at Minnesota.

"When I got to third and I saw (third base coach) Duffy Dyer still waving, I was thinking 'this isn't a good time to be experimenting,'" Steinbach said. "When the second baseman has to go into right field to make the play, that does a lot of explaining right there."
Steinbach's 33rd home run tied Carlton Fisk for the American League record for home runs in a season by a catcher.
Ken Griffey Jr hit his 49th home run for Seattle.
